section.title: Bean archive
section.para: A bean archive is a java archive, such as a jar or a Java EE module, that contains a special marker file: META-INF/bean.xml.
A bean archive may be deploy in a CDI environment. It enables all CDI functionality in that bean archive.

section.title: OSGi bundle
section.para: A bundle is a Java archive, such as a jar or a folder, that contains a special marker file: META-INF/Manifest .MF.
A bundle may be deploy in an OSGi environment. It enables all OSGi functionality for that bundle.

section.title: Bean bundle
section.para: A bean bundle is a java archive that contains both special marker file: META-INF/bean.xml and META-INF/Manifest.MF.
A bean bundle may be deploy in an OSGi environment using Weld-OSGi infrastructure bundle. It enables both OSGi and CDI functionality for that bundle. It also enables Weld-OSGi special functionality.

section.title: Infrastructure bundle
section.para: The infrastructure bundle is a bean bundle that manage all the other bean bundle of the current OSGi application. It manage all CDI relevant functionality and communication.

section.title: References
section.para: This document uses both CDI and OSGi specification documentations as technical references. You may refer to these documents for a better understanding of CDI and OSGi functionality, references and naming conventions.

section.title: What is Weld-OSGi ?
section.para: Weld-OSGi aims at simplifying the access to the OSGi environment by providing a more modern, more user-friendly and faster way to interact with the OSGi Framework.
It addresses the OSGi complexity about services management using CDI specification (JSR-299). Thus it provides an CDI OSGi extension with injection utilities for the OSGi environment.
Moreover an integration with any CDI implementation, such as Weld, is possible through a standard bootstrapping API. An complete integration with Weld is provided.

section.title: What about other frameworks
section.para: Weld-OSGi stays compliant with CDI specification and uses only standard OSGi mechanisms. Every things it does (or nothing from it) CDI and OGSi can do.
Thereby is compatible with most of the current frameworks dealing with OSGi service management.
